comment.author: 91105961@N00
comment._content: Farranfore to Valentia Harbour railway in service from 1893 till 1960. It was the most Western railway in Europe.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/peet] Thanks for the dating info, I've changed the date on this one too! We'll have to start paying you commission - finder's fee for dates...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is a Railway buffs dream, fantastic shot.  I'd imagine it was a nightmare coming back up again?

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: This is the Great Southern & Western inspection car. It was travelling out the Valentia line as it had just been opened, as noted in 1893. The cutting and soil as you can see is still fresh from the construction.

comment.author: 44589582@N08
comment._content: Drung hill was a notable section on this line in having 3 short tunnels in quick succession sitting high on a narrow ledge 270ft over the south shore of Dingle bay and just above the road to Cahirciveen. The line was built under the Light Railway Act of 1889, but it could hardly be called so as it’s costly building (£8,800 a mile) required many sections of heavy engineering, like around distant Drung Hill above. Ironically this part of the line mirrored the northern part of the famous "Ring of Kerry tourist route which gets clogged with large slow moving buses in high season, the railway closing in 1960 just before the age of mass transatlantic tourist travel that might have helped prolonged it's potential. Here's a what remains of the tunnels around the hill, still set above the road for the keen eyed! www.flickr.com/photos/2cme/4953606423/in/set-721576227747... www.flickr.com/photos/2cme/4095848764/in/set-721576227747...

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: When adding this interesting photo to the Clerestory Coaches (Railways) Group, in line with many other photos already there and as only the picture owner can do this, as requested in the group rules, please kindly geotag, where possible, to identify the location of this picture, for the benefit of many of the world wide members! In the new photostream layout, click on "Add this Photo to your map" on the top of the right hand side of the white space. In case of need refer to Slides 2 & 3 in this set. Many thanks.
